tn.ref: Woe to the land of the rustling of wings, which is along the rivers of Ethiopia
tn.text: Possible meanings of "the rustling of wings" are 1) wings represent boats that have sails. AT: "Woe to those who live in the land beyond the rivers of Ethiopia, whose many ships look like insects on the water" or 2) the rustling of wings refers to the noise of insects that have wings, perhaps locusts. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: by the sea
tn.text: The Nile River was very wide, and people in Egypt and Ethiopia referred to it as "the sea." AT: "on the great river" or "along the Nile River" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: vessels of papyrus
tn.text: Papyrus is a tall plant that grows along the side of the Nile River. People bound together papyrus bundles to make boats. AT: "papyrus boats" or "boats made of reeds" or (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

tn.ref: a nation tall and smooth ... a people feared far and near ... a nation strong and trampling down, whose land the rivers divide
tn.text: These phrases all describe the people of one nation.

tn.ref: a nation tall and smooth
tn.text: The word "nation" here refers to the people of that nation. AT: "a nation whose people are tall and have smooth skin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: a people feared far and near
tn.text: The words "far" and "near" are used together to mean "everywhere." AT: "a people who are feared everywhere" or "a people that everyone in the earth fears" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

tn.ref: a nation strong and trampling down
tn.text: Trampling down represents conquering other nations. AT: "a nation that is strong and conquers other nations" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: the rivers divide
tn.text: This probably refers to many rivers that flow through the nation so they divide it into different parts.

tn.ref: Connecting Statement:
tn.text: Verse 3 tells what the messengers in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:18:01|18:2]] must say to the people of the world.

tn.ref: All you inhabitants of the world ... you who live on the earth
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. AT: "All you people on the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: when a signal is lifted up on the mountains, look; and when the trumpet is blown, listen
tn.text: The signal and trumpet were to call people to battle. The commands to look and listen are commands to pay attention and prepare for battle. AT: "pay attention when the signal is lifted up on the mountains and the trumpet is blown"

tn.ref: when a signal is lifted up on the mountains, look
tn.text: The signal was a flag used to call people to battle. This can be stated in active form. AT: "pay attention when you see the battle flag on the mountains"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: when the trumpet is blown, listen
tn.text: The trumpets were used to call people to battle. This can be stated in active form. AT: "pay attention when you hear the sound of the battle trumpets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: General Information:
tn.text: God uses a parable about a farmer in a vineyard in order to describe what he will do to a certain nation. That nation is either Ethiopia or Ethiopia's enemy.

tn.ref: This is what Yahweh said to me
tn.text: "Yahweh said to me." Here the word "me" refers to Isaiah.

tn.ref: I will quietly observe from my home
tn.text: What God will observe can be stated clearly.  AT: "I will quietly observe that nation from my home" or "From my home, I will quietly watch what the people of that nation do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: like the simmering heat in sunshine, like a cloud of mist in the heat of harvest
tn.text: These phrases show how quietly God will watch the nation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Before the harvest
tn.text: "Before the grape harvest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: when the blossoming is over
tn.text: It can be stated clearly that this refers to blossoms on grape vines. AT: "when flowers have finished growing on the grape vines" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: he will cut off the sprigs
tn.text: If a farmer sees that a new branch does not bear fruit, he will cut it off.  AT: "the farmer will cut off sprigs that do not bear fruit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: pruning hooks
tn.text: A pruning hook is a knife that people use to cut branches off of vines or other plants.

tn.ref: he will cut down and take away the spreading branches
tn.text: If a farmer sees that a branch has grown too much and is keeping the whole vine from bearing a lot of fruit, he will cut it off and throw it away. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: They will be left together
tn.text: God seems to change from telling the parable to speaking more directly about the nation. This can be stated clearly. AT: "Those who are killed will be left together" or "Like branches that are cut off and thrown away, the bodies of those who are killed will be left on the ground" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])

tn.ref: The birds will summer on them
tn.text: "The birds will eat them during the summer." The word "birds" refers to birds that eat the flesh of dead bodies.

tn.ref: all the animals of the earth
tn.text: "all kinds of wild animals"

tn.ref: will winter on them
tn.text: "will eat them in the winter"

tn.ref: a people tall and smooth ... a people feared far and near ... a nation strong and trampling down, whose land the rivers divide
tn.text: These phrases all describe the people of one nation. See how you translated these phrases in [[:en:bible:notes:isa:18:01|18:2]].

tn.ref: a people tall and smooth
tn.text: "a people who are tall and have smooth skin"

tn.ref: a people feared far and near
tn.text: The words "far" and "near" are used together to mean "everywhere." AT: "a people who are feared everywhere" or "a people that everyone in the earth fears" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

tn.ref: a nation strong and trampling down
tn.text: Trampling down represents conquering other nations. AT: "a nation that is strong and conquers other nations" See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: to the place of the name of Yahweh of hosts, to Mount Zion
tn.text: The word "name" refers to Yahweh. AT: "to Mount Zion, where Yahweh of hosts dwells" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
